text: A million stars wink in the night desert sky. Down here o insect, one of those big, beautiful, multicolored four-wi effortlessly on the breeze, wafting along through the cri The insect dips, it banks, it does loop-the-loops -- and unceremoniously against the windshield of a white van tha the road.
The DRIVER of the van, a fifty-year-old American, turns o smearing the remains all over.

Goddamn bugs. He squirts some wiper fluid onto the glass, which clears now he sees something worse up ahead. It's a grouping of of them, all pointed at him, sealing off the road. He bites his lip and calls over his shoulder, to the back speaks in Spanish, which is subtitled.
Deja me hablar. (Let me do the talking.)

The van slows to a stop in front of the parked cars, all four doors with "INS" stenciled on the sides. Seven or ei stand in front of the cars imposingly. Their apparent lea and comes to the window. The DRIVER rolls it down. AGENT JANUS, blonde-haired, blu government issue, looks at him and sighs.
Well. Nick the Dick. What a surprise. Where you comin' from?
I was fishing in Cuernavaca.
Sure you were. What do you say we have a look at your catch?

head_text.subj: AT THE BACK OF THE VAN,

text: the Agents fling open the rear doors, revealing a DOZEN F MEXICANS, hopeful immigrants without official permission. looks at the Driver, who's now held by two other Agents, head.
Me, I woulda thrown 'em back. (to the passengers, in Spanish)
Vamanos. Fuera. Hagan una lina! (Let's go. Out. Form a line!)
They pile out of the van. Some are parents with small chi

What do you get, Nick? Hundred bucks a head?  Two hundred? I hope you saved it all for your lawyer, pal, 'cause you're gonna need -- He stops in the middle of his sentence, as another car is fast, its engine WHINING as it barrels down the road towa Agents pull their weapons. The new car pulls a hard right, goes off the road, spins cars, and SQUEALS to a sideways halt, silhouetted in fron headlights. It's a boxy, black 1986 Ford LTD. TWO MEN get out, dressed in plain black suits, crisp whit black ties, shiny black shoes. KAY, fiftyish, is the apot world-weary; his partner, DEE, mid-sixties, is just weary the INS agents.
We'll take it from here.
Who the hell are you? Kay and Dee flash some form of ID.
INS Division 6.
Division 6? I never heard of Division 6.
Really? Kay and Dee move past him and approach the row of nervous
What're we thinking, Dee?
Tough call, Kay. He walks down the row, studying the faces, greeting each Spanish.
!Oye! Que pasa, coma estas? Hey! (What's up, how are you?)
No se preocupe, abuela. Bienvenida a los Estados Unidos. (Don't worry grandma. Welcome to the United States.) (next)
A donde vas? San Antonio? Buscando trabajo, no? Buena suerta. (Where are you going? San Antonio?  Looking for work, aren't you?  Good luck.) (next)
Es un placer verle aqui. (It's a pleasure seeing you here.)
One by one, their faces relax, reassured by Kay's calm de reaches the fifth Guy, he keeps the same cheery tone, but
Que dices si te rompo la cara? (What do you say if I break your face?)
The Guy smiles and nods. Kay stops. His own smile broaden hand on the Guy's shoulder.
No hablas ni una palabra del Espanol, verdad, amigo? (You don't speak a word of Spanish, right, friend?)
Again, the Guy smiles and nods. Kay looks back at Dee.
We got a winner. (to the others)
Los restos estan libres a irse. Largense! (The rest of you are free to go. Scram!)
Sir!
Tomen el camion, y vayeuse. (Get on the road and go.)
Sir, you can't just --
Don't "Sir" me! You have no idea who you're dealing with! Silence on the road. The Driver grins, jumps back in the van. The others pile into the rear and they tear out of t
(to Janus)

We're gonna have a little chat with our friend here. You boys can hit the road ... and keep on protecting us from dangerous aliens. Kay and Dee escort their captive across the road and over leaving the stunned INS agents standing alone in the road
You ever heard of Division 6?
There is no Division 6.
Who are those guys?
Kay and Dee lead their captive into a clearing in the des pulls an enormous handgun from a shoulder holster and sta off, covering him. Kay has an arm draped around the man's
I think you jumped off the bus in the wrong part of town, amigo. In fact, I'll bet dollars to pesos that you're not -- He pulls out a small laser device, which he ZIPS neatly d the man's clothes.

-- from anywhere near here. The man's clothes fall to the ground, revealing what he r underneath -- A SCALY SPACE BASTARD, about four-and-a-hal a snouth, snail-like tentacles, and independently moving the top of his head. The only part of his camouflage not crumpled to the groun humanesque "head," which he still lamely holds in one of propped up by a stick, like a puppet, and it continues to as he holds it.
Mikey?! When did they let you out of jail? MIKEY replies -- an unfathomable combination of GRUNTS, S saliva.
Political refugee. Right.
You know how many treaty articles you've just violated? Mikey makes a lame SQUEAK.
One, my ass. Try seven.
From unauthorized immigration to failure to properly inoculate prior to landing.
(off Mikey's objections)

Okay, that's enough. Hand me your head and put up your arms. From behind Mikey, they hear a terrified GASP. Kay and Dee both look over quickly. One of the alien's ey stalk, whips around too. All three of them see AGENT JANU over the rise, staring in frozen amazement.
Ah, shit. Agent Janus SCREAMS. Mikey rips free of the rest of the " disguise, knocks Dee out of the way, and takes off straig SCREECHING a horrible Space Bastard screech. Janus freeze
Dee! Shoot him! Dee struggles to roll over and change the controls on his out of his hand as he hit the ground.

Dee, for Christ's -- Mikey keeps moving, covering the last few yards to Janus on a rock, launches himself into the air, his dripping ja open -- -- there is a SIZZLING sound, a brilliant white flash -- -- and Mikey ERUPTS in a geyser of blue goo that splatter ground, the trees, and Agent Janus' face. Behind where Mi stands, smoking weapon in hand.
On the road, the INS AGENTS pull their guns and run towar
Kay has an arm around Janus, whom he is leading further i Janus is white, shaking, eyes like silver dollars.
Th -- th -- th --
(helping)
"That."
That wasn't -- wasn't -- wasn't --

Human, I know. Oops. Got some entrails on you. He takes out a handkerchief and wipes off the Agent's fac Janus looks back to where Mikey blew up. Then at Kay. And stars. The other INS Agents burst over the rise, SHOUTING questi

Okay, everybody, situation's under control, calm down. If you'll just give me your attention for a moment I'll tell you what happened. From over the rise, car engines WHINE in the distance and to flash around them. Kay reaches into his pocket and pul metallic device the size of a pocket recorder. He checks figures in his head, then dials an electronic counter on device up to "08."

This is called a "neuralyzer." A gift from some friends from out of town. The red eye here isolates and measures the electronic impulses in your brain. More specifically, the ones for memory. Behind him, six more MEN IN BLACK, all wearing black suit come over the hill. Kay barks a few orders to them.
Gimme a splay burn on the perimeter, please; holes at 40, 60, and 80.
What in the hell is going on?!
Exactly the right question. And the answer lies right -- here. Pay attention.
Who are you, really?

Really? I'm just a figment of your imagination. He holds up the neuralyzer. The Agents peer closely at it into his pocket, puts on his own black sunglasses -- -- and pushes a button on the side of the neuralyzer.  A tenth of a second long sears the Agents' eyeballs. They s
God, we're a gullible breed. Behind him, TONGUES OF FIRE blast from a flame thrower he Men in Black. Kay looks back at the INS Agents, who are j around, as if awakening from a concussion.
I mean it, fellas, you are lucky to be alive after a blast like that. The Agents look around, confused.
What -- blast? Kay gestures behind him, where the Men in Black are now u extinguishers to douse the flames they themselves started
Underground gas vein, genius. You guys need to exercise more caution before discharging your firearms. He jabs a finger into Janus' chest.
Especially you. Dee has moved away from them all and is sitting on a rock the night sky, his sunglasses dangling idly from one hand from the group and finds him. He sits down next to him.
I'm sorry. About...back there.
Happens.
Didn't used to. He holds up his hands, which tremble with age.
The spirit's willing, Kay, but the rest of me... He looks up, at the million stars shining overhead.
They're beautiful, aren't they?
What?
The stars. We never just -- look. Anymore. (back to Kay)
I'll tell ya, Kay. I will miss the chase. Kay pulls his neuralyzer from his pocket and looks down a
No. You won't.

A shot of the clock on the Station's stately southern exp DOWN TO... A pair of feet running. They belong to a man we will know PERPETRATOR. As we track with him, he SPEEDS UP and OUT O A new set of feet come into frame. These belong to JAMES COP in undercover street clothes. In the BACKGROUND, abou behind, are two other cops, trying to keep up. Edwards is a lot faster, though. He pulls out his badge t chain under his shirt.
Stop! NYPD! He continues running, out of frame, and we stay on one of overweight, who gives up the chase and drops to his knees
All yours, Edwards! The Cop fumbles in his pocket for a pack of cigarettes.

head_text.subj: TRACK WITH EDWARDS AND THE PERP

text: As they run down the bridge that traverses Park Avenue in The Perp veers to the left and, seemingly oblivious to th a thirty-foot drop, he hurdles the guard rail, and drops Street below. EDWARDS is surprised by this maneuver, but doesn't waste too, hurdles the guard rail and lands on...

A DOUBLE-DECKER BUS, one of those cheesy sightseers that traffic. The bus, of course, is completely filled with JA and it seems like every single one of them has a video ca EDWARDS pushes through the crowd...
Grand Central Station off to your left, folks... With the bus still moving, he scrambles down the circular out through the side door. He spots the Perp, sailing east on Forty-first Street.
Dammit, man, you're making me sweat up my gear! Edwards spots one of those New York Post delivery trucks, the open back door, rumbling by.  He runs and jumps into
THE PERP, meanwhile, is running at top speed, when Edward frame, leaning off the back of the truck.
Yo, man, your luck just ran out. He leaps from the back of the moving truck and tackles th The Perp, now straddled by Edwards, is terrified.
He's coming! He's coming!

And when he gets here, I'll kick his ass too. Edwards is about to slap the cuffs on him, when the Perp unusual about that, but then another set of translucent, eyelids, underneath his regular eyelids, blinks also. Edwards is thrown for a moment, which is all the time the pull out... His WEAPON, which is the strangest looking gun you've eve quickly, Edwards bats it out of the Perp's hand. THE WEAPON smashes into the stone wall surrounding Centra SHATTERS into a million pieces.

What the... WHOMP! The Perp kicks him in the nuts, then scrambles to takes off again. Edwards staggers after him, in pain. The Perp leaps over a moving car, towards the GUGGENHEIM tries to follow, but a bus pulls in front of him. After i Perp is gone.

Edwards runs over to the Museum, leans over the wall that and in the next instant... The Perp flies past him, having leapt from twenty feet do the Guggenheim. He scrambles up and over the ledge. Edward reacts. He runs to the front door of the Museum, s runs inside. He runs from the rotunda up the grand ramp of the Guggenh

On the roof, the PERP reaches the top, climbs over the ed to the gravel surface. He leaps to his feet and races ove locked. He tugs on another. It's locked too. He pulls on a third. -- revealing EDWARDS on the other side, breathing hard. H at the Perp.
Wassup? The Perp SCREAMS inhumanly and panics. He backpedals, tow the roof.
He's coming! He's coming because I failed, and now he'll kill me too!
Stop!
You don't understand. Your world is gonna end. But the Perp has backed right into the edge of the roof, to fall over. The Perp blinks.
What are you?! The Perp looks down. He decides. -- and he falls, SCREAMING, to his death.
EDWARDS sits on one side of the table, a POLICE INSPECTOR SERGEANT (the one who gave up the chase and lit a cigaret across from him.
Perpetrator then blinked two sets of eyelids. You mean blinked with both eyes?
No, sir. He blinked once with one set, then again with another completely different set.
Sort of a low beam, high beam.
Was that before or after he drew the weapon which you claim evaporated into a million pieces?
After, sir.
And why do you suppose none of the other officers saw either of these two events?
'Cause some of the other officers are a little soggy in the midsection. And they couldn't keep up, sir.
Hey, Edwards, if you were half the man I am --
What do you mean? I am half the man you are.
What the hell is your problem?
My problem is you being all up in my damn face all the time.
I think he threw him off the roof. Ten minutes -- your best shot.
(cutting off the Sergeant)
Sergeant. I want to talk to you outside. Now.
You need ten minutes on a Stairmaster, you pudgy bastard.

A woman sneaks into the room. DOCTOR LAUREL WEAVER, thirt dark-haired, dark-eyed, general aura of darkness around h him. Laurel looks like she was just dragged out of bed (w saw a spaceman (which she did).  She looks over her shoul whispers to him.
Laurel Weaver. Deputy Medical Examiner. I believe you. I opened him up. Find me at the morgue. On 26th. I'll tell you what I found.
Hey...Wait a minute. Wait a minute.
(turning at the door)
You have really pretty eyes. She hurries to turn the corner, but is STOPPED by someone offscreen.
Dr. Weaver, from the coroner's office? Working on the John Doe? Edwards twists in his chair, to get a better look. All he facing whoever it is in the hallway.
Yes. That's right.
Would you look right here, please. The Someone says something else and Laurel steps forward, Edwards's line of vision.

Look where? Edwards stretches even further in his seat, when there is from the corridor. Really curious now, he starts to get u -- when KAY steps into the room and closes the door behin rolls his eyes.
Some night, huh?
Oh, yeah, some night. He crosses to the door.
They were gills. Edwards stops.
Not eyelids.
Who are you?
Did he say anything to you?
(scoffing)
Yeah, sure. He said the world was coming to an end.
Did he say when?
You're kidding, right?
Would you recognize his weapon if you saw it again?
Absolutely.
Let's take a ride.
Wait a minute. I got a ton of paperwork.
It's all done. At that point, the INSPECTOR sticks his head in, smiles a the thumbs up.
Good work, Edwards. Edwards looks at the Inspector, then at Kay. As they leav
You ran that guy down on foot? That's tough. That's double tough.
In a plain, boxy Ford, Kay drives, silent. He raises his a black MIB truck coming in the opposite direction.Edward passenger seat, is still in his undercover outfit.
So who you with? Kay says nothing.
You got the plain clothes, the government-issued wheels. Secret Service?
Kay remains utterly silent.
(referring to the car)
Yeah, well, whoever it is, you're short on funding.
Nothing is what it seems, kid.
Oh, yeah, my bad '86 Ford LTD. That's a luxury ride. C'mon, who ya with? Kay pulls the car to a stop.
I'm part of a secret organization that monitors and polices alien activity on earth. Kay opens the door and gets out of the car. Edwards follo
Edwards looks around. Sees they're standing in front of a
This is where we're going? They get out of the car.
Jack Jeebs? Guy buys from chain snatchers. Doesn't even sell guns.
Really?
All right, you think it's worth shaking him up, fine. I'll do my thing. Then I want some answers.
Do your "thing," kid.  Edwards goes inside.
JACK JEEBS is the sleazy, sarcastic proprietor of the Paw easily intimidated.
Officer Edwards. Oh, hey, geez, how'd these get here? I thought I turned 'em in to the proper authorities. He casually brushes some Rolexes off the counter.
Way I hear it, Jeebs, you into something a little hotter than some stolen Rolexes.
Sure -- I'm a big crack dealer now. I just work here because I love the hours. This pisses Edwards off. He grabs Jeebs by the collar.
(getting angry)
I'm talking about guns, Jeebs. High-tech stuff.
C'mon, Edwards, whatcha see is what I got.
Why don't you show him the imports, Jeebs. At the sound of Kay's voice, Jeebs suddenly pales, a look over his face.
H-hiya Kay, how are you?
The imports, Jeebs. Now.
You know I got outta that business a long time ago, Kay.
Why do you lie to me? I hate it when you lie. He pulls his own gun and aims it at Jeebs' forehead.
Whoa, whoa, Kay, hold on a minute here...
I'm going to count to three. Edwards, seeing that Kay is getting somewhere, joins in t
He'll do it, Jeebs.
One.
I've seen him do it.
Two.
Talk to me, Jeebs, he's crazy when he's like this.
He's always crazy. (to Kay)
Take a cruise. Get a massage --
Three. KA-BOOM! Kay blows Jeebs' head off and Jeebs' body collap Edwards is shocked. Edwards pulls his own weapon and points it at Kay's head.
Put down the gun and put your hands on the counter!
I warned him.
Drop the weapon!
You warned him.
You are under arrest. You have the right to remain silent.
Will you relax?
(irritated)
Don't do that. Edwards whirls around to see Jeebs' BODY, growing another four or five seconds. Kay calmly shoves his gun up agains baby-soft new cheek.
Do you know how much that hurts?

Show us what you got, Jeebs. Or I'll use up another one. Jeebs, panicked, hits a button on the underside of the co promptly flips over, revealing yet another dusty shelf, p junk -- -- but this is all alien junk. Weapons, mostly, bizarre, weapons of all shapes and sizes.
Edwards? Edwards, still dazed by Jeebs' regrown head, glances down weapons.
Uh, this. This is what I saw. Kay looks at Jeebs, pissed off.
You sold a carbonizer with implosion capacity to an unlicensed cephlapoid.
He looked all right to me.
A carbonizer is an assassin's weapon, Jeebs. Who was the target?
I don't know. Kay raises the weapon again, threatening.
Jeebs!
I don't know! Kay lowers his gun, gestures to the shelf full of weapons
This is all confiscated. All of it. I want you on the next transport off this rock. Or I'll shoot you where it doesn't grow back. Jeebs nods, point taken. Kay leaves.
Yeah. I'll be by tomorrow for those Rolexes. Shaken, Edwards follows.
Edwards staggers out of the shop, trying to get the day's in his head.
The eyelids, fine ... and the jumping thing ... and the gun ... okay, but the head?
Searching for a handle on the moment here? A place to file all this.
See a head doesn't do that, it doesn't just grow back. (looking up)
What's going on?
Can't help you, kid. Only comfort I can offer is that tomorrow, you won't remember a thing.

Oh, no. This I'm gonna remember for a long, long time. Kay pulls the neuralyzer from his pocket. He hesitates fo moments -- as if this particular neuralyzation is differe others. Then he puts on his sunglasses.
Ever see one of these?
-- the flash dims on EDWARDS and KAY, sitting at a table restaurant.
(finishing a joke)

-- and the wife says yeah, Harry, I know, but this one's eating my popcorn! He busts out laughing. Edwards, across from him, is compl disoriented. He looks down. There's a half-eaten order of and several empty bottles of beer on the table in front o
Huh? Kay checks his watch.
Whoops. Gotta run. Thanks for the egg rolls.
Where am I?
See what I mean about tequila? You're a bright young man, James. Just lay off the sauce. I'll see you tomorrow, nine a.m. sharp. He turns and walks out. Edwards checks his watch. A WAITR
Another beer?

Coffee. Please. She walks off. Edwards looks at the table. There is a bus next to his plate, on which Kay has handwritten "James D. Saturday, 9 a.m., 504 Battery Drive." Edwards looks at it, puzzled. He turns the card over and other side. There's not much there, no name, no phone or e-mail address. Just three little letters, dead in the mi

A lonely farmhouse stands amid the fields of upstate New country. Several lights are on and through a window we ca silhouette of a MAN sitting at the kitchen table, the sil WOMAN hovering over him, bringing things to him. The Man (EDGAR) waves his arms, ranting.

I go out, I work my butt off to make a living, all I want is to come home to a nice clean house with a nice fat steak on the table, but instead I get this -- this -- I don't even know what you call this! In the sky above, it's one of those brilliant star fields strange is happening with one of those stars -- it's gett

I'll tell you what it looks like, it looks like poison. Don't you take that away, I'm eating that, damn it! It is poison, isn't it?! No, that star isn't getting bigger, it's moving. Toward u from a pinpoint to a dime, to a nickel, to a quarter, and into fruit metaphors.

I swear to God, I would not be surprised if it was, the way you skulk around here like a dog been hit too much -- or ain't been hit enough, I can't make up my mind. Okay, we're way past watermelon now, that thing is huge, to glow hot red as it enters the earth's atmosphere, head toward us, coming here, to Beatrice and Edgar's place. The blazing fireball barrels through the sky, SNAPS off a

You're useless, Beatrice! The only thing that pulls its weight around here is my goddamn truck! -- and SLAMS right through a pickup truck parked in the d concussive BLAST follows, then a geyser of smoke and flam

Stay here! The silhouette of Edgar leaps to its feet, races to the d it open. Edgar is everything his voice led us to expect - bug-eyed redneck carrying a twelve-gauge shotgun. His mou walks across the yard and stares at the hulking shell tha The skeleton of the truck is still there, but there's a h hole in it, a hole that goes at least ten feet down into

Figures. He walks to the truck and touches the door handle. Hot. U tail, he opens the door and peers down into the hole. IN THE HOLE, he sees a smooth curve of metal and a few bl Embedded into the ground is, indeed, a spaceship, maybe e BEATRICE calls from behind him, standing in the doorway f
What is it, Edgar?!
(turns to her)
Get your big butt back in that house! Beatrice does as she's told, closing the door behind her. to the smoldering rock, raising his shotgun in defense. A VOICE comes from deep in the hole.
Place projectile weapon on ground. Edgar staggers back a step, terrified. But then he regain the weapon, and steps forward, pointing it menacingly dow
You can have my gun when you pry it from my cold, dead fingers! There is a pause while the voice thinks about this offer. responds, in a voice and cadence remarkably similar to Ed

Your proposal is acceptable. A long, hairy pincer flashes out of the hole, grabs Edgar pulls him down into the hole. From deep in the hole, we hear a terrible RIPPING sound, being torn in half. There are some disgusting GUSHY sound later, something flies out of the hole and FLOPS onto the the truck. It's Edgar. Well, sort of. His body parts still hang toge arms, legs, even clothes -- but everything inside has bee he just lies there, flat and empty, like a tuxedo on the prom. The shotgun flies out and lands beside him.

BEATRICE sits at the kitchen table, terrified, still wipi from Edgar's diatribe. The door opens and EDGAR comes bac kitchen, seemingly fleshed out again, leaving the door ha him. He carries the shotgun. She looks up at him, anxious. But his face is a blank.
What on earth was it?! He looks at her strangely. When he speaks, his voice is d before. More refined.
Sugar. Pause. She looks out the window, at the smoking truck.
I've never seen sugar do that.
Give me sugar. Puzzled, Beatrice gets up, goes to the cabinet, and grabs She holds it out to him.
In water. Frightened, she takes a glass of water from the table. Sh the sugar into it.

More. She puts more, till the glass is brimming. She stirs it q knife and hands it to him, her hand trembling. Edgar takes it and downs it in a single gulp. Beatrice st idea what to think. She notices something odd about the s

Edgar, your skin! It's -- it's -- just hanging off your bones! Edgar drops the glass and looks in a window, to catch his reaches up -- -- and twists his whole face, as if adjusting a ski mask, skin of his neck back into his shirt collar.  He looks at
That better? Beatrice faints.

Stillness. Silence. A loud SCRAPING sound comes from the spaceship. The nose of the ship itself rises up out of the pit, wave and finally CRUNCHES to the ground outside the pit. EDGAR climbs out of the pit, breathing heavily. He dusts continues pushing the ship, along the ground, off into th

The next morning. EDWARDS, holding the small MIB business hand, compares the address written down by Kay to the add utterly nondescript building in front of him. It's seven gray, windowless, perfectly square, squatting on a bridge a fat guy on the john. "504 Battery Drive."

EDWARDS steps through a heavily barred metal door and int room. One wall is entirely dominated by the enormous blad vent air intake. There is an elevator at the far end of t OLD SECURITY GUARD, the rent-a-cop kind, reading a comic metal chair halfway across. Edwards walks across the room, his footsteps ECHOING. The
Help you?
Maybe, I'm not sure, see, I got this card --

Elevator. Push the "call" button. And he goes back to his comic book. Edwards, maybe out of than curiosity at this point, walks across the room, towa As he draws close, the elevator doors WHOOSH open, expect

Edwards steps inside and turns around. The doors close. H "call" button and waits, but the elevator doesn't move. I the other side of the elevator slide open silently behind waits, unaware. From behind him, somebody clears their throat. Edwards tu finds himself standing in --

This back room is every bit as mysterious and unfamiliar Standing at the front of the room is ZED, a wire-haired c old school bureaucrat, wearing the exact same kind of sui night. SIX OTHER HOT RECRUITS sit in egg-shaped chairs, s Edwards. One chair is empty.
You're late. Sit down. Edwards takes the remaining chair. The elevator doors sli continues addressing the Recruits.
My name is Zed. You're all here because you're the best of the best. Marines, Navy SEALS, Army Rangers...NYPD. They all turn and regard Edwards a little smugly. He give

And we're looking for one of you. Just one. What will follow is a series of simple tests designed to quantify motor skills, hand-eye coordination, concentration, stamina -- I see we have a question. Edwards's hand is, indeed, up.
Why, uh -- I'm sorry, it's just no one really asked this, but -- why, exactly, are we doing this? Silence. Then one of the young recruits eagerly raises hi on him.
Son?
(loud and formal)
Jake Jensen, West Point, graduate with honors. We're here because you're looking for the best of the best of the best, sir! Edwards tries to stifle a laugh, but can't.
What's so funny, Edwards?
I -- I don't know, sir. This guy. "Best of the best of the best of the best of the --" (realizing nobody is with him on this)
It just struck me as -- (totally serious)
Humorous. Sir. Short pause. Then Zed continues.
Okay. Let's get going.

The recruits scribble away at the written test. It's a th reasoning skills, general knowledge, diagrams.  The RECRU really powering through it, filling in answer after answe But no desks have been provided for them, and they're all chairs, writing uncomfortably on their thighs or knees. EDWARDS is really struggling. He writes two words on one decides to erase it. The lack of a writing surface is dri his pencil even TEARS through the page. He looks up. In the middle of the tile floor, there is an Edwards gets up, goes to it, grabs hold -- -- and drags it, SCREECHING DEAFENINGLY, back to his chai looks up, wincing at the horrible sound that fills the ro Edwards sits back down, now writing on the table.  That's Zed raises an eyebrow. He stares at Edwards, then looks u smoked glass window. Behind the dark glass, a FIGURE stan unemotional.

SEVEN WEAPONS rest on a table in the middle of an otherwi triangular room. The SEVEN RECRUITS stand in front of the There's an odd moment -- where everyone sort of looks aro other, at the blank walls...
Anyone, uh...any of you guys know what we're doing here?
(clipped, unquestioning)
Looking for the best of the best of the best.
(can't help but smile)

Well, yeah, I know, but... And then .. suddenly -- The two far walls pull apart. The whole room pulsates and suddenly filled with a bewildering swirl of stroboscopic human and alien. Everywhere is color, light and movement mass of strange shapes and characters moving simultaneous The Recruits lunge for the weapons, snapping them up and SHOTS are fired at once. And then, a second later, a SEVE fired. Everyone sort of looks at Edwards, who puts his gu There's an awkward silence. Then the door opens. Light po with it. Even the highly competitive cadets can't help bu sympathy as Zed walks straight to Edwards.
The hell happened?
